huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~9000~4250~25–35~28.5~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
Archery: Most hunters are able to locate 20-40 bucks a day.  The Book Cliffs has one of the highest success rates for archery hunters in the state.  Some hunters are disappointed in the quality of bucks so I would suggest trying to spend some time in the area to become familiar with the steep terrain and the quality of bucks.  There are not many 30” bucks on this unit.  The average buck harvested on this unit is basically a 22” 4 point or 3 x 4.  This area provides challenging terrain in a remote part of the state.    

There are other hunts that coincide with the archery deer hunt.  They are: limited entry elk, limited entry bear, bear pursuit, and upland game hunts.  In the past deer hunters have had negative experiences with bear hunters in the area.  Please be aware that everyone has an equal right to hunt this area.  The Book Cliffs is an incredibly large area, but during summer and early fall most of the animals are congregated in a small area.  If you really want to get away from ATV and vehicle traffic I would plan on hunting in the Little Creek WMA (roadless area).
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs has a high bear population.  Keep a clean camp and put your garbage in a place that is inaccessible to bears. If you do have problems with bears please report them to the DWR Northeastern Regional Office as soon as possible (435 781-9453), or call the local dispatch center (435 789-4222).      

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah.  There are no service stations for many miles.  Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Archery: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  Thunder storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.  Most hunters struggle with trying not to get there meat to spoil in the heat.  I would plan on hot weather and plan accordingly.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Archery: Location of harvest: You will find the majority of the deer located along the Divide Road. The Book Cliffs range divides the north from the south with a long ridge that runs east to west. The Seep Ridge Rd becomes the Divide Rd and runs east to Colorado and West to Steer Ridge. The Book Cliffs has limited summer range. The majority of the deer are going to be located along the Divide Rd. The deer will be relatively close to water sources. There are numerous springs in the heads of the steep canyons. The local ranches keep small ponds and reservoirs full, but don’t rely on them to always be full of water. Some of the areas where hunters have harvested in the past are: Rat Hole Ridge and Canyon, Rail Road Canyon, Black Horse and Saddle Horse Ridge, PR Springs, Horse Point, Moon Ridge, Cherry Mesa, Rock Springs Mesa, Cedar Camp, Steer Ridge, and Little Creek Ridge. The elevation plans a key role in where you will find deer during this time of year. I suggest if you are not seeing deer to change your elevation. Migration Patterns: The mule deer migrate to the higher elevation in late spring. They fawn on their summer range and most of the bucks stay on the summer range until they strip their velvet. The Book Cliffs is limited by summer range which can make the archery hunt a very successful hunt. By mid-October the deer start to migrate to their winter range and can be found in the transitional zone. There is a large transitional area where the deer can hole up until winter storms start to move them to their winter range. From past biological studies we have found that approximately two thirds of the deer migrate to the north and approximately one third of the population migrates to the south. Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential. Scouting is most effective the last couple weeks before the hunt opens when they are more likely to stay in the same general area. I would scout the higher ridges where oak brush is prominent. Your preseason scouting can really pay off on this hunt. The deer won’t start to leave the high country until mid-October. The bucks might not be on the same ridge, but I would expect them to stay with-in a five mile radius. In the hot early fall temperatures I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset. There are several recovering burned areas along the Divide. The oak brush is starting to get more established and creates great habitat for mule deer. Behavior: Like other wildlife, they are most active in the early mornings and evenings. Their behavior is dictated by the weather as well. Rain provides more areas for them to drink, and can eliminate a need to travel more sustainable water sources. The bucks will still be in bachelor groups of three to as many as ten in a group. They will often bed down together so it can be difficult to close the distance. They will tend to use the same game trails and with good pre scouting you might be able to pattern a bucks movements. I would expect their behavior to change after all of the hunting pressure from opening weekend.

Muzzle Loader:
Migration Patterns: The mule deer migrate to the higher elevation in late spring. The does fawn on the summer range, and most of the bucks stay on the summer range until they strip their velvet. The Book Cliffs has limited by summer range. By mid-October the deer start to migrate to their winter range and can be found in the transitional zone. This is a large area where the deer can hole up until storms start to move them to their winter range. This area is made up of a lot of pinyon/juniper trees, mahogany, bitter brush, sage brush and grasses. From past biological studies we have found that approximately two thirds of the deer migrate to the north. Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential. Scouting is most effective the last couple weeks before the hunt opens when they are more likely to stay in the same general area. I would scout the higher ridges where oak brush is prominent. Your preseason scouting can really pay off on this hunt. The deer won’t start to leave the high country until mid-October. The bucks might not be on the same ridge, but I would expect them to stay with-in a five mile radius. In the hot early fall temperatures I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset. There are several recovering burned areas along the Divide. The oak brush is starting to get more established and creates great habitat for mule deer. Behavior: Like other wildlife, they are most active in the early mornings and evenings. Their behavior is dictated by the weather as well. Rain provides more areas for them to drink, and can eliminate a need to travel more sustainable water sources. The bucks will still be in bachelor groups of three to as many as ten in a group. They will often bed down together so it can be difficult to close the distance. They will tend to use the same game trails and with good pre scouting you might be able to pattern a bucks movements. I would expect their behavior to change after all of the hunting pressure from opening weekend. General Information: Most hunters are able to locate 20-40 bucks a day. The Book Cliffs has one of the highest success rates for archery hunters in the state. Some hunters are disappointed in the quality of bucks so I would suggest trying to spend some time in the area to become familiar with the steep terrain and the quality of bucks. There are not many 30 in bucks on this unit. The average buck harvested on this unit is basically a 22” 4 point or 3x4. This area provides challenging terrain in a remote part of the state. There are other hunts that coincide with the muzzleloader deer hunt. They are: limited entry elk, limited entry bear, bear pursuit, and upland game hunts. In the past, deer hunters have had negative experiences with bear hunters in the area. Please be aware that everyone has an equal right to hunt this area. The Book Cliffs is an incredibly large area, but during summer and early fall most of the animals are congregated in a small area. If you really want to get away from ATV and vehicle traffic I would plan on hunting in the Little Creek WMA (roadless area). Rifle:
Location of harvest: The deer will be relatively close to water sources until it snows. There are numerous springs in the heads of the steep canyons. The local ranches keep small ponds and reservoirs full, but don’t rely on them to always be full of water. There are four main drainages that have streams. They are: Willow Creek, Sweet Water, Bitter Creek, and Evacuation Creek. The deer will be congregated around these areas because they are key water sources while they migrate off higher elevations. The east side of the Book Cliffs borders Colorado, and there are several deer later in the hunt that migrate down from Colorado. Some of the areas where hunters have harvested in the past are: Flat Rock, Agency Draw, Willow Creek, Wood Canyon, Indian Ridge, PR Springs, McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, Big Park, Wolf Den, Atchee Ridge, Three Mile Canyon, Evacuation Creek, Park Canyon, and Rabbit Mountain. The elevation plays a key role in where you will find deer during this time of year. I suggest if you are not seeing deer to change your elevation. Migration Patterns: The mule deer migrate to the higher elevation in late spring. The does fawn on the summer range, and most of the bucks stay on the summer range until they strip their velvet. The Book Cliffs has limited by summer range. By mid-October the deer start to migrate to their winter range and can be found in the transitional zone. This is a large area where the deer can hole up until storms start to move them to their winter range. This area is made up of a lot of pinyon/juniper trees, mahogany, bitter brush, sage brush and grasses. From past biological studies we have found that approximately two thirds of the deer migrate to the north. Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential. Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens. During this time the bucks are not likely to stay in the same general area. It would be best to come out a few days before the hunt opener to find the elevation where the majority of the bucks are located. I would scout the transitional areas. I would not plan on scouting during the late summer or early fall for this hunt. The deer will start to leave the high country until early to mid-October. I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset. There are several recovering burned areas on McCook Ridge. Behavior: Like other wildlife, deer are most active in the early mornings and evenings. Their behavior is dictated by the weather as well. As the hunt progresses I would expect to see the bucks become more active during the day. Rain and snow provides much needed drinking water for deer, and can eliminate a need to travel to more sustainable water sources. The bucks will be breaking up from their bachelor groups. I would expect their behavior and routine to change after all of the hunting pressure from opening weekend

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Ownership is approximately 95% Public Land - BLM, and State lands.  There are small isolated tracts of private lands representing less than 5% of the unit.  These private lands include the mouths of most the major canyons coming out of the Book Cliffs and the irrigated fields near the town of Green River.  These private lands will be more of an impact for deer hunters than pronghorn or bighorn sheep hunters.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Nash Wash WMA.  It is accessed from Exit 204 off of Interstate 70.  It will be a very good area for mule deer but marginal for pronghorn and bighorn sheep.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: The only developed campground on the unit is at Swasey's Beach along the Green River and is administered by the BLM. It is a good campground that is very near good sheep hunting opportunities.   Dispersed camping opportunities on SITLA and BLM lands across the desert are abundant.  Firewood and water are relatively scarce.  Plan on bringing your own water.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: The yellow 1:100,000 scale BLM maps named Westwater, Huntington, and Moab.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
ATV and Vehicle Access: allowed on approved roads and trails

Bighorn Sheep: Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on its Travel Management Plan. There are only a few roads that go on or near bighorn sheep habitat on the unit. The Hastings Road just east of the Green River in the town of Green River will take you along the east side of the Green River for about 15 miles until the road dead-ends near Rattlesnake Canyon. This road will provide the closest access to where most of the sheep live. This road is graded by the county and is generally in good shape. There are some tight spots along the river that you should be wary of if there is snowy or icy conditions. The Tushar Canyon road will go northeast off of the Hastings Road about 9 miles north of the town of Green River. It will access the right and left fork of Tushar Canyon and loop around along the bench to the east and provide access to Coal, Horse, and Floy Canyons. The Coal Canyon Road is the first right hand turn off of the Hastings Road while still in the town of Green River. It will go through a bunch of alfalfa fields and then up on the cliffs. the Horse Canyon and Floy Canyon roads can be access by following the frontage road along I-70 to the east. Despite all of these directions, most of your time will be spent on foot.

Deer: The main areas with the highest concentrations of deer include Nash Wash (Exit 204 off of Interstate 70), Cottonwood Canyon (Exit 214), Hay Canyon (Exit 221), and Bitter Creek (Exit 227)

Pronghorn: Use any exit off of Interstate 70 or drive the frontage road along the Interstate. Major access points include Green River (Exit 164), Floy Wash (Exit 175), Crescent Junction, Thompson, Yellowcat, Nash Wash (Exit 204), Cottonwood (Exit 214), Sulphur Canyon (Exit 221), and Bitter Creek (Exit 227)
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
Bighorn Sheep: The northern boundary of this unit adjoins Ute Tribal lands along Coal Creek. This is good bighorn sheep habitat and bighorns have been seen on both sides of the boundary near the mouth of Coal Creek. Take great care not to hunt or trespass on these tribal lands. The upper Tribal Boundary at upper elevations near Sego Canyon generally doesn't have bighorn sheep during November. There are small isolated pieces of private property in the mouths of Coal, Horse, Floy, and Thompson Canyons. County roads go through these properties so it is best to simply travel through them and park on public lands if you do not have written permission to hunt on these private lands. Bighorn sheep generally do not spend a great deal of time on these private lands.

Pronghorn: There is a large block of private land on the alfalfa fields near the town of Green River. Antelope use this area. Please secure written permission prior to hunting these private lands. The remainder of the private lands on this unit either do not occur in Pronghorn habitat or are scattered and unmarked.

Deer: Deer concentrate on private lands at the mouths of Cottonwood, Hay, and Bitter Creek Canyons. Please secure written permission prior to hunting these private lands. They are relatively small parcels so they are easy to avoid but they do concentrate deer.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand County--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the summit and drainage divide of the Book Cliffs; west along this summit and drainage divide to Diamond Ridge; southwest along Diamond Ridge and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); west along this boundary to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey’s Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River; east along I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north along this state line to the summit and drainage divide of the Book Cliffs. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THE BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Moab, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas. Private lands make up less than 5% of the total area and most are posted "no trespassing".
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Little Creek WMAs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
DWR WMA’S:  There is a 14 day limit on WMA’s, and there is no camping on the Willow Creek WMA.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trail head starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Primary Access Points:  There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trailhead starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.    

ATV and Vehicle Access: 
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.  The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.   

This unit includes the Book Cliffs Little Creek WMA (Roadless Area).  There is no vehicle access in this area and you are limited to horse or foot travel.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.  

There are some private ranches that post their property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the White River; south along this state line to the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide); west along this summit and drainage divide to Diamond Ridge; southwest along Diamond Ridge and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); west along this boundary to the Green River; north along the Green River to the White River; east along this river to the Utah-Colorado state line. EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Vernal, Price, Westwater, Seep Ridge. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal Office, 435-781-9453.
